newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo palladium futures dive by daily limit.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo palladium futures dive by daily limit.

text.p: Yen-based Tokyo palladium futures fell sharply on Friday, on aggressive private investor selling triggered by expectations that Russian exports of platinum group metals (PGM) would resume soon, Japanese traders said.
All months except for limitless May fell by their 24 yen per gram daily limit by the close. Benchmark April palladium was off 24 yen to close at 581 yen.

"Private investor selling accelerated in the afternoon as Russia's resumption of PGM exports are now in sight," a trader said. Platinum prices ended also lower on the heels of palladium, while gold was narrowly mixed.

A resumption in Russian PGM exports would be bearish for the market, traders said. But prices could stay volatile for a while due to a large overhang of short positions in TOCOM palladium futures and because of overseas funds' commitment to NYMEX and the spot market, traders said.
"Even if Russia resumes PGM exports, a possibility remains that palladium could spike higher as overseas funds are seen trying to squeeze TOCOM shorts," one trader said.
Gold futures moved in tandem with the currency market.
Gold futures ranged from four yen per gram lower to three up. Benchmark April was down one yen at 1,267 yen.
Spot gold was quoted weaker at $341.75/342.25 per ounce at 0808 GMT, against $342.40/90 in New York on Thursday.

In gold futures, market focus remained on the currency market. "Private investors were seen selling gold when prices rose, assuming that the dollar may weaken again, while spot gold is likely to be sandwiched within a range," a trader said.

Concerns over possible gold sales by European central banks and strong physical demand below $340 has trapped gold into a range, they said. Benchmark April silver was down 1.9 yen per 10 grams at 175.5 yen.
